column1: Chosen by Majestic Vinho Verde DOC 2022
column2: We sent our award-winning buying team all around the world on an exciting new mission: to curate a new collection showcasing the best examples of key regions and core grape varietals – at wallet-friendly prices. A long-time favourite of Majestic wine customers, Vinho Verde is more popular than ever. And no wonder – its easy-drinking style is hugely appealing. Our buyers tasted hundreds of wines to find the best expression. It’s made from traditional grape varieties Loureiro, Arinto, Trajadura and Avesso grown in Portugal's coolest region in the far north of the country. Here, the cooling influence of the Atlantic helps create wines that have the perfect balance of aromatic intensity and freshness. It’s crisp and dry, with a mouthwatering minerality. Relatively low in alcohol at 11% with a touch of residual sweetness, it’s an ideal pairing for fresh seafood dishes.

column1: Casa de Vila Nova Filipa de Lencastre Alvarinho Vinho Verde DOC 2021
column2: Owned by the Lencastre family, Filipa de Lencastre is produced near the town of Penafiel, close to the eastern edge of the Vinho Verde wine region. They’re one of a few esteemed local producers who are transforming the image of Portugal’s popular refreshing ‘green wine’ into a food-friendly pour worth taking seriously. Usually fresh, light and easy-drinking, this is a more grown-up rendition. Made entirely with zingy Alvarinho grapes, it comes with impressive complexity. The 2021 bottling won silver at the highly respected Decanter World Wine Awards.
column9: Bread, Citrus Fruit, Earth, Tropical Fruit

column1: Casal de Ventozela Alvarinho 2021/22, Vinho Verde DOC
column2: Casal De Ventozela produces one of our most popular Vinho Verdes out of the native Arinto grape variety. Its Alvarinho (Albariño in Spain) is extremely fresh with flavours of citrus and apple. Complexity and depth are added by ageing in oak barrels and time spent on its lees. This is great with any seafood, especially if cooked with a touch of chili.
column9: Wet Stones, Citrus Fruit, Green Apple, Peach, Pear

column2: When James Martin recommended Porta 6 red on Saturday Kitchen it quickly became one of our most popular wines. Naturally, we wanted to introduce an equally delicious example of Portuguese white wine. We opted for a classic: Vinho Verde. It’s Portugal’s signature glass of white – you’ll be offered it in every bar, restaurant and street-side café from Lisbon to the Algarve. The winery sits on the edge of the Atlantic. Cool ocean breezes help retain freshness in the grapes prior to picking. And that's clear from the first sip. It’s crisp and thirst-quenching with zingy citrus in abundance. The gentle, refreshing spritz makes it an excellent apéritif – or else try it with seafood.

column1: Casal de Ventozela Vinho Verde DOC 2021/22
column2: Vinho Verde is in the far north of Portugal, a cool area with tempering Atlantic breezes and frequent rainfall. This unique climate retains acidity in grapes, giving this wine its bright, crisp finish. Expect aromas of white pepper, green apple and citrus fruit. Its aromatic complexity makes it a superb match for lightly-spiced dishes and seafood.

If Port is Portugal's signature red, then Vinho Verde is its flagship white. It's a light, spritzy apéritif – served in practically every Lisbon restaurant. And this is made by Calcada, the Vinho Verde experts. With a relatively low alcohol content (just 10%) this is a seriously thirst-quenching, drinkable wine. It’s fresh and zesty with lime and lemon flavours. With peachy, slightly floral aromas, it’s perfect with fresh salads or lightly spiced seafood.

column1: Morgadio Da Torre Alvarinho 2019, Vinho Verde
column2: If you love citrusy Spanish Albariño, you need to try Alvarinho from Portugal – it’s the exact same grape. Its heartland is in the Vinho Verde region. With vineyards set back from the Atlantic, and hotter summers than elsewhere in the DOC, this wine has a more generous body and character than the average bottle.
column9: Citrus Fruit, Green Apple, Peach, Spice

column2: Vinho Verde is the star white wine of Portugal. If you like yours refreshing, easy-drinking, lower in alcohol and perfect to enjoy in the sun, you're in for a treat. This one is made by a family-owned winery, now in the hands of the third generation, that has over 100 years of experience in the art. You can taste the Atlantic influence in these crisp flavours of lemon, lime and white melon.  It also has a light spritz that's fantastic with crab.

Originally hailing from the Vinho Verde region, Antonina Barbosa is one of Portugal’s most exciting winemakers, as well as head honcho of Falua, Tercius’s parent brand. The company was founded in 1994 to revitalise terroir-driven winemaking in Portugal’s lesser-known Tejo region, and business has boomed since then. Low yields help them maintain both quality and a sense of place in the wines. With a gold-medal win at the Decanter World Wine Awards and a 94-point score from lauded critic Robert Parker, the wines of Tercius have landed serious international acclaim. And this one impresses with its freshness, bountiful red-fruit aromas and smooth-as-silk profile.
column9: Cranberry, Red Cherry, Red Fruit, Violet

column1: Quinta do Casal Branco 'Reserva Branco' 2020, Tejo
column2: Like rich white Burgundy, but not the high price it commands? You're in for a treat with this discovery from Tejo, Portugal, which is crafted by two of the region's very best winemakers on a 17th century estate. It's made from the indigenous Fernão Pires grape variety, which grows on old vines, and aged in oak. Expect flavours of citrus, tropical fruits and toasty cedar. It's a truly indulgent white wine that will stand up to plenty of foods, particularly a rich casserole.

column1: Casa Ermelinda Freitas Alicante Bouschet Reserva 2019, Setúbal
column2: Harvested from some of the oldest Alicante Bouschet plots in Portugal, this wine shows off all that’s loveable about the Iberian grape variety: it’s big, it’s fruity and it’s wonderfully concentrated. The perfect pour if you’re craving a bottle with serious personality.
column9: Black Fruit, Blackberry, Earth, Sweet Spice

column2: The grapes for Herdade de Gâmbia have been plucked from vines near Portugal's Sado river, just south of Lisboa. The vines are a magnificent backdrop to one of Portugal's most well-protected wildlife reserves. The wine is delicious proof that a harmonious ecosystem contributes to flavour-packed grapes and flourishing vines. Each sip of Herdade de Gâmbia ripples with intense notes of plum, dark cherry and subtle spice.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£11.99 per bottle,75CL,Fernão Pires,Verdejo
column7: Stone Fruit, Citrus Fruit, Cream, Floral

column2: We asked our store managers to select a new wine to be stocked nation-wide. They picked this from a huge pool of contenders. The Agenda Red is a delightfully soft and rounded wine with loads of plum and bramble flavours, plus a touch of herbs. Judicious use of oak adds a slight spiciness to the finish. This will be perfect with roast lamb and rosemary.
column9: Spice, Black Plum, Blackcurrant Leaf, Herbaceous

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£8.99 per bottle,75CL,Castelão,Touriga Nacional
column6: Spice, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry

column2: Love Porta 6? We’ve gone one better. When James Martin recommended Porta 6 on Saturday Kitchen it quickly became one of our most popular wines. It seemed impossible to improve on it. But we had a feeling that if Porta 6 is an exceptional wine – we could make a truly extraordinary one. We challenged the producer to go into the vineyards and root out the very best parcels of grapes. What they discovered were grapes of such incredible quality they warranted extra special care and attention. They handpicked and carefully sorted the grapes, then slowly aged the wine in oak barrels. The resulting wine is richly fruity with a twist of charred BBQ spice – it’s like Porta 6 but smoother, richer and even more delicious. Amp up the flavours by pairing it with spicy grilled meats.
column9: Vanilla, Jammy, Red Fruit, Sweet Spice

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2018 vintage.\",£12.99 per bottle,75CL,Touriga Nacional,Shiraz
column6: Vanilla, Jammy, Red Fruit, Sweet Spice

column2: Portuguese red blends are a Majestic speciality. They're easy-drinking, rich, packed with juicy fruit flavours and great value. Not to mention, they're a bit out of the ordinary. We look for a blend of exotic Portuguese grape varieties to give you something a little different and a lot more exciting. And we've really stepped up our game with this exclusive box. It's made by one of Portugal's most-awarded producers in homage to Lisbon's legendary food scene. It's big. It's bold. It's very drinkable – all brambly fruit with a kick of spice. Plus, it'll enhance any richly flavoured food you throw at it, whether that's barbecue or a warming casserole.
column9: Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry, Spice

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2019 vintage.\",£10.99 per bottle,75CL,Touriga Nacional,Tinta Roriz
this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£8.99 per bottle,75CL,Tinta Roriz,Touriga Nacional
this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£9.49 per bottle,75CL,Castelão,Touriga Nacional

Every year, the city of Lisbon is transformed into a lilac paradise by the blossoming of jacaranda trees. These flowers are a symbol of summer – and we wanted to capture that spirit in a wine. Made by Casa Santos Lima, one of Portugal’s most respected producers, this is a bright and vibrant blend that’s full of Mediterranean charm. Discover aromatic notes of strawberry, raspberry and redcurrant. Its crisp acidity and fresh, mineral character will pair beautifully with seafood and light salads.

Portuguese red blends are rich, packed with juicy fruit flavours and great value. Not to mention, they're a bit out of the ordinary. None of your bog-standard red grapes here - we look for a blend of exotic Portuguese natives to give you something exciting. This one is made by one of Portugal's most awarded winemakers. Expect brambly fruit and a kick of spice. Put this magnum centrepiece when serving casserole.
column9: Spice, Black Fruit, Black Plum, Blackberry

column2: this wine won an IWC award for the 2020 vintage.\",£9.99 per bottle,75CL,Trincadeira,Syrah

Marquês de Borba is leading the way in sustainable wine farming in Portugal’s Alentejo. Here, João Maria Ramos, the son of João Portugal, one of the country's most-famous winemakers, is a champion of lesser-known indigenous varieties and artisan techniques. He produces great wines from old vines (vinhas velhas) in Estremoz. Here a blend of red grapes is foot-trodden in traditional lagares tanks then aged in oak barrels. The result? A full-bodied and velvety wine that packs intense sunshine flavours into every sip. Think black fruit, eucalyptus and spice. Pair it with roasted meats such as lamb, venison or duck, or richly flavoured vegetarian casseroles. James Suckling gave the 2019 vintage 92 points.

column1: Wind and Waves Alvarinho 2022, Vinho Verde DOC
column2: Quinta da Calçada are one of the oldest producers in Vinho Verde’s Amarante region. The Lago Cerqueira family built their cellars here in 1917 – and over a century later, their wines have gone from strength to strength. This is an elegant expression of Alvarinho—known in Spain as Albariño— thanks to the subregion’s high elevation. Due to the vineyard’s lofty altitudes, grapes benefit from the warm, sunny days and cooler nighttime temperatures. The result? Ripe, juicy flavour balanced by a refreshing acidity. Expect floral hints and notes of tropical fruit and citrus. The refreshing acidity and minerality makes it a great part for fried fish dishes like calamari or fresh sushi and sashimi.

column1: 10 year old Malmsey Henriques and Henriques Madeira 50cl
column2: This Madeira is made solely from Malmsey, one of four classic grape varies on Madeira. Fortified and aged in Canteiro, or dockside warehouses, the wine oxidises, giving it its characteristic colour and flavour. Intense coffee and raisin aromas with caramel and complex spicy aromas. Luxurious sweetness, silky textured fruit on the palate, bracing acidity and integrated fortifying spirit with a fantastic finish. Madeira is all but indestructible, once open the bottle will not deteriorate. Enjoy as an after dinner drink or with toffee pudding.

column1: Henriques and Henriques 3 Year Old Full Rich Madeira 50cl
column2: This classic Madeira undergoes the unique Estufa process where the wine is repeatedly warmed than cooled for 90 days making the wine stable before it three years of cask ageing. Lucious, rich, sweet and fragrant this is full of intense flavours of dried fruit and caramel. Try this on it own, or with a classic Madeira cake.

Late-bottled vintage port is aged in oak for up to six years. This means it's deliciously mature and ready to drink when bottled. Made by one of the greatest Port houses, this is dense and smooth, with flavours of blackcurrant jam, mint, cigar box and cedar, and a very long finish. Pair with hard cheeses.

Croft is the Port industry’s oldest producer still active today. Founded in 1588, the house has a rich and fascinating history. Their innovative thinking saw them create the very first vintage Port, and the house continues to lead the way with some of the region’s finest fortified wines. This Reserve Tawny is a prime example. It’s beautifully smooth and round, with warm aromas of butterscotch, walnut and spice. Ripe and jammy fig flavours will complement a strong cheddar or a dark chocolate dessert.
this wine won an IWC award for the 2013 vintage.\",£36.99 per bottle,75CL,Tinta Barroca,Touriga Nacional

Founded in 1815, Fonseca has a centuries-old reputation for decadent vintage Port. Sourced from their flagship estate, the Quinta do Panascal bottlings are famed for their distinctive character and vibrancy. Crafted using sustainably grown fruit, grapes are foot-trodden in traditional cement tanks and then aged in oak barrels. This 2008 vintage is a pure expression of the estate's slopey, riverside terroir, with opulent notes of cassis, black cherry, dark chocolate and sandalwood.
column6: Tinta Barroca, Tinta Cao, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Franca

column2: The 10 Year Old Tawny is drawn from a reserve of fine wood ports which have been aged to full maturity in seasoned oak casks, each holding about 630 litres of wine. The individual wines are then blended to guarantee consistency of quality and house style.

column1: Taylor's Historical Collection 'The Mallet' Reserve Tawny Port
column2: In the 1720s, Peter Bearsley, the son of the founder of Taylor's, was the first person from the English wine trade to embark on the Douro Valley, the picturesque home of port. Today, Taylor's is widely considered the gold standard of aged tawny port. This one is made in tribute to their great history, and the bottle is how it would have looked centuries ago. Expect opulent notes of coffee, butterscotch, plum and dried fruit. The perfect digestif.
column6: Tinta Barroca, Tinta Cao, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Franca
column9: Black Plum, Date, Fig, Raisin, Red Plum, Sweet Spice, Toffee, Walnut

column2: Portuguese blends are a Majestic speciality – and this seamless seven-grape white blend was too good to pass up. It's from the Douro – a hot, dry region best known for producing robust, full-bodied wines, including Port. So how is this wine so light, crisp and refreshing? It's down to winemaker Luís Sottomayor. He carefully chooses grapes from high-altitude vineyards where the temperatures are cool and yields are low. So vines produce grapes full of freshness and intense flavour. It’s full of tropical and zingy citrus flavours. Something this refreshing and aromatic cries out for grilled octopus with chilli and lime.

This is made by two of Portugal's best-known winemakers, José Maria Soares Franco and João Portugal Ramos. Both have played crucial roles in modern-day Portuguese winemaking. And this is the perfect way to discover the reds of the Douro Valley. The area gained its fame producing Port, but today that’s just the tip of the iceberg. Its steep, exposed vineyards are cooled by the Douro river and deliver juicy, aromatic reds. Expect notes of blackberry, hints of wild thyme and soft tannins. Fantastic with mature cheeses.
column9: Violet, Black Fruit, Earth, Red Fruit, Spice, Vanilla

column1: Quinta do Portal 'Mural' Reserva Tinto 2020, Douro
column2: With a rich winemaking history dating back to 1881, Quinta do Portal is a “boutique” family winery known for its premium Douro wines. Paulo Coutinho has been the head winemaker here since 1994 – and his attention to detail is second to none. Only the best grapes make the cut before they’re harvested by hand. Once picked, the grapes are taken to the winery in small baskets before they’re fermented at low temperatures to retain their freshness. 25% of the wine is aged in seasoned French oak casks and then blended with wine aged in stainless steel tanks. The result? The perfect balance of fresh flavour and complex notes of spice. Expect floral aromas with flavours of ripe black fruit and toasty hints. Its concentrated flavours and firm structure makes it the perfect wine to enjoy with meat dishes and hard cheeses.
column9: Black Cherry, Black Fruit, Floral, Vanilla

column1: Quinta do Portal ‘Muros de Vinha’ 2021, Douro
column2: Quinta do Portal is a boutique Portuguese winery, now in its fourth generation of family ownership. Up in the steep slopes of the Douro Valley, Paulo Coutinho manages plots worked by the family since 1881. He’s been head winemaker here since 1994 – and it’s safe to say he’s perfected his craft. Utilising a range of planting techniques depending on the gradient of the slopes, he ensures only the finest Touriga Franca, Tinta Roiz and Tinta Barroca grapes are handpicked for this blend. Discover flavours of ripe red fruits, spicy notes and hints of vanilla. It’s dense yet elegant – a perfect match for roast meat dishes.

Taylor's is one of the oldest and most respected Port houses. They began in 1692 and made their name catering to British tastes with hedonistic Ports made on the upper Douro Valley. Vintage Ports are the pride of their production – and this one is particularly special. It has intense aromas of blackberry, black cherry, plum and liquorice, ripe, smooth tannins and jammy fruit flavours on the finish. Try it with strong blue cheese.
this wine won an IWC award.\",£15.99 per bottle,75CL,Touriga Franca,Touriga Nacional

This is a rich, full-bodied port made from white grapes on the dizzying Douro slopes. It's deliciously fragrant with notes of honey and oak and a long, smooth finish. Serve with 2/3rds premium tonic water, over ice, and add a slice of orange and a sprig of mint for an excellent long drink.

Fonseca's port has been enjoyed in the UK since 1840. They take great pride in their ruby port. It's aged for several years in wooden vats to encourage complexity and soften tannins while keeping fresh flavour. It's full-bodied with intense flavours of blackcurrant and cherry. Excellent with soft cheeses.

This is a special edition that celebrates the year when Taylor's discovered fantastic new Douro vineyards. It's made from specially selected ports from the house's extensive stocks and is exceptionally rich. It has aromas of plum, fig and sultana and flavours of fruit cake. Excellent with a cheese board.
column6: Touriga Franca, Tinta Barroca, Tinta Cao, Tinta Roriz
Touriga Nacional, Tinta Amarela, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Franca
